description: From Late Latin armistitium, from Latin arma (“arms, weapons”) + sistēre (from sistō (“to halt, stand still”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *steh₂- (“to stand up”)) + -ium (“suffix forming abstract nouns”). The word is cognate with French armistice, Italian armistizio, Portuguese armistício, Spanish armisticio.

entries.meaning: A (short) cessation of combat; a cease-fire, a truce. [from late 17th c.]
A formal agreement, especially between nations, to end combat.
